It's a type of cell. â€¢ What does a neuron do? - Receive input from other neurons at the synapses and if required conditions are satisfied, produce an output (a spike train) through the axon. Biological Neuron A neuron receives electrical signals through the axons terminals of other neurons. These signals have to cross a gap (called the synaptic cleft) at the synapses before entering the dendrites that carry the signal into the cell body (soma). What portion of the signal passes onto the dendrites will depend on the strength of the particular synapse. In modeling neurons, the input signal at each synapse is multiplied by its strength (weight ), w. Therefore, the resultant signal received by the cell body is the weighted sum of the pre-synaptic signals. If the signal present at the cell body is large enough to cause sufficient depolarization of the neural membrane, the neuron will fire and a voltage spike called an action potential will be transmitted through the output axon. There are two types of synapses; excitatory and inhibitory. Excitatory synapses cause membrane depolarization and contribute to fire the neuron. Such synapses are modeled with positive weights Inhibitory synapses cause membrane hyperpolarization and inhibit the firing of the neuron. Deng et al. Neural Networks, 2020 Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) How does an SNN work? â€¢ At each point in time each neuron has some value. â€¢ The value in a neuron can change based on the mathematical model of a neuron â€¢ e.g, if a neuron receives a spike from the upstream neuron, the value might increase or decrease. â€¢ If the value in a neuron exceeds some threshold, the neuron will send a single impulse to each downstream neuron connected to the initial one. â€¢ After this, the value of the neuron will instantly drop below its average. â€¢ Over time the value of the neuron will smoothly return to its average. How to Model a Neuron? https://snntorch.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorials/tutorial_2.html How to Model a Neuron? â€¢ Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) â€¢ The most popular model. â€¢ When input spikes show up, the potential is incremented/decremented based on the synaptic weight for that input. â€¢ When inputs are absent, a leak is subtracted. â€¢ The increments/decrements are step functions (unlike the smooth curves in this figure). SNN Architectures â€¢ Feedforward NN â€¢ Data is transmitted strictly in one direction â€¢ Recurrent NN â€¢ Connections between neurons form a directed graph along a temporal sequence. â€¢ Hybrid NN â€¢ Consists of both feedforward and recurrent connections. How to Train an SNN â€¢ Still a research problem â€¢ Training SNN might be a difficult task â€¢ Not differentiable â†’ Cannot use gradient descent. â€¢ Unsupervised â€¢ Spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) â€¢ Growing Spiking Neural Networks â€¢ Supervised â€¢ SpikeProp â€¢ Remote Supervised Method (ReSuMe) How to Train an SNN â€¢ Spike-Timing-Dependent Plasticity (STDP) Rule â€¢ Initially, all synaptic connections have equal weights. â€¢ The magnitude of change in synaptic weight â€¢ Depends on the timing of spikes. â€¢ If the presynaptic spike arrives at the postsynaptic neuron before the postsynaptic neuron fires (it causes the firing), the synapse is potentiated. â€¢ If the presynaptic spike arrives at the postsynaptic neuron after it is fired, the synapse is depressed. Deep Learning with SNN â€¢ Theoretically possible â€¢ Spiking Deep Neural Networks are not as good as traditional Deep Neural Networks Advantages and Disadvantages of SNNs â€¢ Advantages â€¢ SNN is dynamic â€¢ An SNN can still train when it is already working; â€¢ Better for speech and dynamic image recognition. â€¢ SNNs usually have fewer neurons than the traditional ANNs; â€¢ SNNs can work very fast since the neurons will send impulses not a continuous value; â€¢ SNNs have increased the productivity of information processing and noise immunity since they use the temporal presentation of information. â€¢ Disadvantages â€¢ Hard to train. â€¢ Performance is not comparable to ANNs YET.
